text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen 
in this video I'm going to answer hopefully

all of your questions about lemongrass 
which is an absolute staple in any Thai

kitchen if you want to learn more about 
Thai ingredients I do have some other

videos on other ones and I will be making 
more so make sure you subscribe so you

don't miss those and I'll be putting them 
all in a nice little playlist I'll put the

links of that playlist in the description 
below and up here and let's get started

lemongrass in Thai is called Takrai and this 
is probably how you see it at your grocery

store it grows out of the ground right here 
but up top here there's actually very long

leaves that come out and the leaves are very 
sharp do ever go near by a lemongrass bush do

not grab the leaves just you know willy-nilly 
because it can cut you now one misconception

about lemongrass is that it is sour okay 
lemongrass even though it's called lemon

does not have any taste in meaning it doesn't 
have any sweet sour salty umami anything we

use it for it's aroma which is citrusy and 
lemony but a little grassy ER I know that

sounds really obvious but if you smell 11 
versus lemongrass you'll know what I mean

the first thing to know is when you get a stock 
like this the flavor is concentrated over here

not at the top so when I cook with lemongrass 
I always cut the top off and I save that for

stock or for tea okay now the bottom I also 
remove because that's that's a hard root that

you can't use I usually peel off one layer 
on the outside or two depending on how dirty

it is cuz this use this layer is usually pretty 
dry now once you get down to here this is where

flavor is concentrated there are a few ways you 
can use it if you're using soup you can smash

it you can use the back of your knife or if you 
have a pestle you can smash it release the aroma

that's inside those cells mmm that smells good 
already cut it into chunks throw it into soups

it only takes 3 to 5 minutes to get the flavor 
out into a liquid in that form though you cannot

eat it because this is very very tough so treat 
it more like a cinnamon stick let it infuse and

then you discard it after okay now if you want 
to actually eat it you can but you have to cut

it very very fine you can toss it into salad add 
it in to dips throw it into stir fries and it's

small enough that you can chew it and it's not 
gonna be a problem for you mmm smells so good

starring unless I know I'm using it within the 
week I always freeze my lemongrass so what I

do is I cut off the parts that I don't use 
I freeze the top separately by the way for

my stalks I cut off the root end that I don't 
want and then I freeze it in chunks so I usually

cut you know something like this put these in 
freezer bags and then freeze them and they'll

last quite some time if you want to make them 
last even longer wrap these in foil first before

you put it in a freezer back because foil 
is impermeable to air which causes freezer

burn and I find that that really prolongs 
the life of herbs in general in the freezer

if you cannot find fresh lemongrass there 
are frozen dried pastes and even powdered

and it kind of depends on what you need it for 
my first question that I would ask is does that

recipe meet the lemongrass because sometimes it's 
just one of the many vini flavors that are going

on if you leave it out it'll still be okay okay 
your next best bet is generally frozen so this

is the only kind of frozen lemongrass I can find 
at my local store it's just chopped up lemongrass

that's frozen I have a feeling that this is 
the entire stock of lemongrass you know not

like for me I only use the strongest part of the 
lemongrass they probably didn't and it also has

food coloring added to it to make it more green so 
I don't love it for that but you know if you could

probably add this to a curry paste and it would be 
okay powdered I've never used but again that would

probably work it may be a dip or a curry paste 
there's dried lemongrass like whole pieces of

lemongrass that's dried I have had success with 
that in soups but not in any other application

okay so think about what this you're making and 
also whether you can leave it out altogether

some of you may think that lemon zest might work 
and and it's it's close-ish but lemon I find has

a much sweeter aroma compared to lemongrass 
that you will end up with a very drastically

different result so I tend to just not go that 
route and that is it I hope that was helpful

and if you have more questions reach out to 
me on Facebook Twitter Instagram or through

my website Hawkeye kitchen com if you've got 
tips or tricks about lemongrass please share

with us in the comments below I'm sure people 
would love to find out about it if you haven't

subscribed to the show make sure you do and 
don't forget to check out the playlist on other

ingredients link is in the description below 
and I refute I'm for your next TV [ __ ] time
